'''Stuart Margolin''' (born January 31, 1940) is an [[United States|American]] [[film]] and [[television]] [[actor]] and [[Film director|director]].
==Television== Margolin is best known for his role on the [[television]] show ''[[The Rockford Files]]'', playing Evelyn "Angel" Martin, the shifty friend and former cellmate of Jim Rockford ([[James Garner]]). Margolin won the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor â Drama Series]] in this role, in 1979 and 1980;<ref>[http://cdn.emmys.tv/awards/awardsearch.php Advanced Primetime Awards Search] at Academy of Television Arts and Sciences website (retrieved April 18, 2009).</ref> he is one of only four actors to win this award twice for the same role.<ref>Tom O'Neil, [http://goldderby.latimes.com/awards_goldderby/2010/07/drama-supporting-actors-prove-emmy-winners-not-always-tv-reruns.html "Drama supporting actors prove Emmy winners not always TV reruns"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', July 13, 2010.</ref>
Margolin played Rabbi David Small in the 1976 movie, ''Lanigan's Rabbi'', based on the series of mystery novels written by [[Harry Kemelman]]. Scheduling conflicts prevented him from continuing the role in [[Lanigan's Rabbi|the short-lived TV series of the same name]] that aired in 1977 as part of the "NBC Sunday Mystery Movie," where Small was played by Bruce Solomon. Margolin was earlier paired with James Garner in a 1971-72 TV [[Western (genre)|Western]] series entitled ''[[Nichols (TV series)|Nichols]]'', where he played a character somewhat similar to the Angel character he played in ''The Rockford Files''. That show only lasted for one season. Margolin appeared in two episodes of the television series ''[[M*A*S*H (TV series)|M*A*S*H]]'' ("Bananas, Cracker and Nuts", "Operation Noselift"), ''[[The Mary Tyler Moore Show]]'', ''[[Rhoda]]'', an episode of ''[[Land of the Giants]]'' ("The Mechanical Man"), ''[[The Monkees (TV series)|The Monkees]]'' ("Monkees Watch Their Feet"), ''[[Love, American Style]]'', ''[[The Fall Guy]]'' and ''[[Magnum, P.I.]]'' His brother [[Arnold Margolin]] was the [[executive producer]] of the ''[[Love, American Style]]'' series. In May 2009, Margolin appeared on an episode of ''[[30 Rock]]'', opposite [[Alan Alda]];<ref>Alan Sepinwall,[http://www.nj.com/entertainment/tv/index.ssf/2009/05/30_rock_mamma_mia_alan_alda_is.html "30 Rock, "Mamma Mia": Alan Alda is the Donaghy daddy?"], ''[[The Star-Ledger]]'', May 8, 2009 (retrieved May 19, 2009).</ref> it was the first time the two actors appeared together since ''M*A*S*H'' in 1974. Margolin appears in the 2009 [[CTV Television Network|CTV]]/[[CBS]] [[police drama]] series ''[[The Bridge (TV series)|The Bridge]]''.<ref>[http://www.hitfix.com/articles/2009-2-20-flashpoint-pipeline-brings-the-bridge-to-cbs 'Flashpoint' pipeline brings 'The Bridge' to CBS.]</ref><ref>Mary McNamara, [http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/tv/la-et-thebridge-20100710,0,7388391.story "Television Review: 'The Bridge' on CBS"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', July 10, 2010.</ref>
==Film== Margolin appeared in films such as ''[[Kelly's Heroes]]'', ''[[Death Wish]]'', ''[[Futureworld]]'' and ''[[The Big Bus]]''. Stuart Margolin also played Sheriff in a black and white episode of ''[[Gunsmoke]]''.
==Directing== Margolin has been directing TV shows since the early 1970s, including episodes of ''[[The Mary Tyler Moore Show]]'', ''[[Magnum, P.I.]]'', ''[[Bret Maverick]]'', ''[[Quantum Leap (TV series)|Quantum Leap]]'', and ''[[Northern Exposure]]''. He has appeared in a number of Canadian television series including some produced by [[Doug McLeod]]. He won the 1996 [[DGA Award]] for children's programming for directing the film ''[[Salt Water Moose]]'', and he was nominated again for the same award for directing the 1998 film ''[[The Sweetest Gift (film)|The Sweetest Gift]]''. Margolin was also nominated for a DGA Award for [[Directors Guild of America Award for Outstanding Directing - Drama Series|drama series direction]] for a 1991 episode of ''[[Northern Exposure]]'' entitled "[[List_of_Northern_Exposure_episodes#Season_2:_.28Spring_1991.29|Goodbye to All That]]".<ref>[http://www.dga.org/news/pr_expand.php3?130 "DGA Announces 1998 Nominees For Outstanding Directorial Achievement In Documentary And TV Categories Of Daytime Serials And Children's Programs"], at DGA website, February 8, 1999 (retrieved January 4, 2009).</ref> He also directed, co-starred and scored ''[[The Glitter Dome (film)|The Glitter Dome]]'' (1984) with [[James Garner]], [[Margot Kidder]] and [[John Lithgow]] for [[HBO Pictures]].<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0087340/]</ref>
==Other== Margolin has authored several songs for and with long time friend and singer-songwriter [[Jerry Riopelle]] that have appeared on Riopelle's albums since 1967. He was in the bands [[The Parade (band)|The Parade]] and [[Shango (rock group)|Shango]], and co-wrote Shango's 1969 novelty record "Day After Day (It's Slippin' Away)".<ref>Jerry Osborne,[http://www.courierpress.com/news/2007/Jan/1/prominent-albums-make-comeback/ "Prominent albums make comeback"], ''[[Evansville Courier & Press]]'', January 1, 2007 (retrieved January 7, 2009).</ref> He also released an album in 1980 entitled ''And the Angel Sings''.
Since 2004, he has been a regular participant in the theatre program of the [[Chautauqua Institution]].<ref>Sharon Cantilon, [http://www.buffalonews.com/entertainment/arttheater/story/375882.html "The Secret's Out: Chautauqua Institution's theater program is gaining national attention, thanks in part to actor Stuart Margolin"] ''[[Buffalo News]]'', June 22, 2008 (retrieved January 4, 2009).</ref>
Margolin is sometimes erroneously identified as the brother of actress [[Janet Margolin]].<ref>[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CE7DA1131F93BA25751C1A965958260&scp=2&sq=janet++margolin&st=nyt "Janet Margolin, Film And TV Actress, 50"], ''[[New York Times]]'', December 18, 1993.</ref><ref>[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0DEED91239F93AA15754C0A964948260&scp=3&sq=janet++margolin&st=nyt "Benjamin Margolin"], ''[[New York Times]]'', July 29, 1982.</ref>
